Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Novel biocatalysts based on artificial metallo-cofactors in flavoproteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Lutz (1546790)

The proposed work will generate proof-of-concept data on re-engineering the active site of the flavoprotein, Old Yellow Enzyme (OYE), to perform hydrocarbon chemistry aimed at producing chemicals that are difficult to synthesize by non-biological approaches. To this end, the proposal will focus on creating new artificial biocatalysts by integrating catalytically active organometallic complexes in the active cofactor site in the interior of the enzyme. The new biocatalysts so-formed will be assessed for their potential to catalyze C-C bond forming reactions. Moreover, the general approach of substituting artificial prosthetic co-factors has potential for general applicability to many areas of chemical synthesis and chemical conversion to useful products. The project will also feature educational components to train students in the diverse engineering and scientific disciplines required for success in the bioengineering area, and will continue the principal investigator's (PI's) involvement in a number of programs aimed at increasing interest and education in STEM areas amongst underrepresented minorities in the greater Atlanta area.

The proposal capitalizes on the utility of flavin-dependent oxidoreductases as enzymes capable of biocatalysis at the laboratory scale. Specifically, the PI and his students will create new artificial biocatalysts by integrating catalytically efficient copper-bis(oxazoline)(Cu-BOX) complexes in the active site of Old Yellow Enzyme. Although challenging, the PI is well positioned to carry out this synthesis successfully based on more than three years of work in his lab on OYE which has already demonstrated substantial improvements in the enzyme's native redox activity. These studies have confirmed the PI's capability to make substantial changes in the active site without compromising the overall structural integrity of the enzyme. The modified enzymes will then be tested for catalytic activity via asymmetric cyclopropanation of styrene and ethyl diazoacetate, a benchmark reaction for C-C bond formation. By exploring new possibilities for the flavoprotein, the incorporation of artificial cofactors based on organo-metallic ligands could dramatically expand the toolbox for biocatalysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catalytic processes play a major role in industrial applications reaching from bulk to fine chemicals, energy production and active pharmaceutical ingredients. An attractive alternative to traditional chemo catalysts are enzymes; highly efficient, selective and sustainable bio-catalysts that typically operate under environmentally benign conditions. Beyond the existing functional diversity of natural enzymes, the catalytic performance of enzymes can be tailored through protein engineering, making them attractive catalysts for a wide range of green chemistry processes.

As part of our NSF-sponsored research, we explored enzymes that recruit prosthetic groups - small-molecule cofactors such as flavins, thiamines or pyridoxals to perform critical biocatalytic functions. These cofactors are typically responsible for the chemical reactivity of biocatalysts while the surrounding protein scaffold modulates their reactivity and controls substrate specificity, as well as regio and enantioselectivity. Such modular catalyst design offers significant functional versatility and originally inspired our thinking about novel biocatalysts with artificial, synthetic cofactors for reactions with no known equivalent in natural enzymes. Among the possible artificial cofactors, organometallic complexes frequently used for C-H bond activation and C-C formation were of particular interest as these types of reactions offer the possibility for directly introducing new functionality in a virtually unlimited range of substrates including hydrocarbons, complex organic molecules and polymers. More specifically, we studied the integration of copper-ligand complexes in the active site of the flavoprotein Old Yellow Enzyme (OYE) by replacing its natural cofactor flavin mononucleotide. While experimental challenge with these artificial, organometallic cofactors proved insurmountable within the one-year funding period, a parallel study to prepare and apply flavin cofactor analogs to probe fundamental questions of protein folding and function was successful. 

Past studies of flavins in enzymes have largely focused on the cofactor’s role in biocatalysis and specifically their impact on chemical reactivity. In contrast, few reports have addressed questions related to their role on protein folding and structure. Over the course of this project, we discovered that the latter function of cofactors is critical for some enzymes, actively contribute to the correct assembly of catalytically competent biocatalysts. To further probe the specific contributions and broader relevance of flavin cofactors to protein folding, we synthesized a series of novel flavin analogs and deployed them to measure their contributions to protein assembly. These experiments conclusively demonstrate the critical role of flavin mononucleotide in the formation of catalytically competent OYE and offer new insights into the sequence of folding events that lead to active enzyme. More generally, our results suggest a far more diverse functional contributions of small-molecule cofactors to biocatalysis. These findings could directly impact the successful preparation of engineered enzyme variants by affecting correct formation of protein structure and stability. In addition, it presents a new dimension for protein engineering and design, offering an novel parameter to find biocatalysts with superior function for a particular chemical reaction.

Beyond the scientific merits of the work, the project has offered an intellectual framework for laboratory team members at all stages of their professional training. The challenges of flavin analog synthesis and the implementation of the subsequent biochemical studies required extensive collaboration and the success reflects effective teamwork of all parties involved. The broader community has also benefited from this work through publications and the oral dissemination of our findings by team members at the national and international level. Finally, outreach activities including elementary and high school teachers and students, as well as the Georgia-wide Science Olympiad were made possible by the support of the NSF.
